comments.body: Should add a comment here explaining that these are messy because they are generated from the C file (and explain how to generate them)

As explained below, these are copypasted from `libf2c`, and the compiler will detect (and does detect) any missing/incorrect definitions (see all of the new warnings that the compiler previously missed). I this case, I don't believe that time should be spent on the aesthetic issue, but rather the compiler warnings (and in another PR).

I'm a little wary of the fact that either:
* You created this manually
* You created this with an automated process that isn't documented in a way that can be repeated in future.

Should we perhaps have the script check the list of headers in this file against the ones it removed from the source, and print out warnings/errors if some are missing?

These headers come directly from `libf2c` (specifically, some random gh repository).

> Should we perhaps have the script check the list of headers in this file against the ones it removed from the source, and print out warnings/errors if some are missing?

The compiler can check this as long as there are no inline prototypes (which is why inline prototypes are a really bad idea). The only script that we need to write is one which will remove the inline prototypes, which is what I have done here.
Can you link to that random repo? Does this include the `Subroutine` declarations too?

I think it's [here](https://github.com/juanjosegarciaripoll/f2c/blob/master/include/f2c.h). But again, all that's required is to remove the inline prototypes and the compiler will check consistency. It's not required to trust that these definitions are correct.

> the compiler will check consistency. I

Is that true if one is missing? (hence my question)

The one you link to [at juanjosegarciaripoll/f2c](https://github.com/juanjosegarciaripoll/f2c/blob/master/include/f2c.h) doesn't match the [debian package](
https://anonscm.debian.org/cgit/collab-maint/f2c.git/tree/f2c.h)...

> Is that true if one is missing? (hence my question)

Yes. There is only a problem when the prototypes are inconsistently defined across multiple files.
